conclusion: Problem involves two harmonic transverse waves propagating along positive and negative x-axis directions.
Wave sources are at x = -0.2 m and x = 1.2 m, both waves have speed of 0.4 m/s and amplitude of 2 m.
At time t = 0, particles P and Q at x = 0.2 m and x = 0.8 m are just starting to vibrate.
Particle M is located at x = 0.5 m, need to find when the two waves meet.
Two waves: one traveling right from x = -0.2 m and one traveling left from x = 1.2 m.
Both waves have the same speed, covering equal distances in the same time.
At t = 0, waves have reached particles P and Q.
Wave traveling right has reached P at x = 0.2 m, wave traveling left has reached Q at x = 0.8 m.
To find meeting time, determine when leading edges of waves reach the same point.
Denote v = 0.4 m/s (wave speed), x_P = 0.2 m, x_Q = 0.8 m, x_M = 0.5 m.
Relative speed of waves is v_relative = v + v = 0.8 m/s.
Distance between sources is d = 1.4 m.
Waves start from respective sources and move towards each other.
Distance they need to cover to meet is not the entire 1.4 m.
Since waves have same speed, they meet where sum of distances traveled equals initial distance between sources.
Denote d = 1.4 m (distance between sources), t is the time when they meet.
Distance traveled by wave from left is d_left = v * t.
Distance traveled by wave from right is d_right = v * t.
Equation: d_left + d_right = d.
Solve: 2v * t = 1.4 m, t = 1.75 s.
Reconsideration due to waves starting from different points and particles P and Q vibrating at t = 0.
